p: The actions at the human-animal interface displayed in Table 3 included measures to decrease the risk of viral shedding from human to human [ 37, 38], from animal to animal [ 38, 39], and from animal to human [ 40]. Further actions targeted the identification and understanding of pathogen reservoirs [ 38, [41], [42], [43], [44], [45], [46], [47], [48]], and awareness-raising on the diseases [ 45, [49], [50], [51], [52]]. The identified actions operated on various spatial levels: household level, i.e. to make dairy and meat safe for consumption [ 10, 38] and the pasteurization of camel milk [ 40]; farm level, i.e. rapid identification of sick camels and their isolation [ 38, 47]; abattoirs level, i.e. standardized protocols for the operation [ 38]; country and regional level, i.e. limitation of livestock mobility between neighbouring countries [ 38], improvement in the laboratoriesÂ´ capacities [ 41, 42, [53], [54], [55]], the collaboration between institutions for a coordinated response to outbreaks [ 56], and the improvement of surveillance and monitoring [ [57], [58], [59], [60], [61], [62]].
